title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement jonthegeek@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to bespoke
text: document outlines propose change bespoke.

title: Contributing to bespoke
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to bespoke
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to bespoke
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("macmillancontentscience/bespoke", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to bespoke
text: part, new code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. addition guidelines tidyverse style guide, ask prefix unexported functions create . (e.g., .my_internal_function). use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to bespoke
text: Please note bespoke project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Creating a Bespoke Model
text: work oils data modeldata. dataset consists 96 samples commercial oils, belongs one 7 classes oil: corn, olive, peanut, pumpkin, rapeseed, soybean, sunflower. ’ll construct function choose class simple properties input data.
code: data(oils) summary(oils) #>     palmitic        stearic          oleic          linoleic     #>  Min.   : 4.50   Min.   :1.700   Min.   :22.80   Min.   : 7.90   #>  1st Qu.: 6.20   1st Qu.:3.475   1st Qu.:26.30   1st Qu.:43.10   #>  Median : 9.85   Median :4.200   Median :30.70   Median :50.80   #>  Mean   : 9.04   Mean   :4.200   Mean   :36.73   Mean   :46.49   #>  3rd Qu.:11.12   3rd Qu.:5.000   3rd Qu.:38.62   3rd Qu.:58.08   #>  Max.   :14.90   Max.   :6.700   Max.   :76.70   Max.   :66.10   #>                                                                  #>    linolenic       eicosanoic      eicosenoic           class    #>  Min.   :0.100   Min.   :0.100   Min.   :0.1000   corn     : 2   #>  1st Qu.:0.375   1st Qu.:0.100   1st Qu.:0.1000   olive    : 7   #>  Median :0.800   Median :0.400   Median :0.1000   peanut   : 3   #>  Mean   :2.272   Mean   :0.399   Mean   :0.3115   pumpkin  :37   #>  3rd Qu.:2.650   3rd Qu.:0.400   3rd Qu.:0.3000   rapeseed :10   #>  Max.   :9.500   Max.   :2.800   Max.   :1.8000   soybean  :11   #>                                                   sunflower:26

title: Creating a Bespoke Model
text: now, simply return random choice row data. develop package ’ll create realistic use case.
code: random_baseline <- function(new_data, n_classes) {   # Return a number between 1 and n_classes for each row of input.   return(     sample(seq_len(n_classes), nrow(new_data), replace = TRUE)   ) }

title: Creating a Bespoke Model
text: case need specifically tell “model” many classes . likely make standard parameter available bespoke functions future. object now behave like model objects!
code: oil_fit <- bespoke_classification(   class ~ .,    oils,    fn = random_baseline,    n_classes = 7 )

title: Creating a Bespoke Model
text: Note case predictions completely random.
code: oils_no_classes <- oils[, 1:7] head(oils_no_classes) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   palmitic stearic oleic linoleic linolenic eicosanoic eicosenoic #>      <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1      9.7     5.2  31       52.7       0.4        0.4        0.1 #> 2     11.1     5    32.9     49.8       0.3        0.4        0.1 #> 3     11.5     5.2  35       47.2       0.2        0.4        0.1 #> 4     10       4.8  30.4     53.5       0.3        0.4        0.1 #> 5     12.2     5    31.1     50.5       0.3        0.4        0.1 #> 6      9.8     4.2  43       39.2       2.4        0.4        0.5 predict(oil_fit, new_data = head(oils_no_classes)) #> # A tibble: 6 × 1 #>   .pred_class #>   <fct>       #> 1 soybean     #> 2 soybean     #> 3 rapeseed    #> 4 sunflower   #> 5 peanut      #> 6 pumpkin predict(oil_fit, new_data = head(oils_no_classes)) #> # A tibble: 6 × 1 #>   .pred_class #>   <fct>       #> 1 corn        #> 2 rapeseed    #> 3 corn        #> 4 rapeseed    #> 5 soybean     #> 6 corn

title: Creating a Bespoke Model
text: course main point compare models. use case, bespoke provides parsnip-style model, bespoke(). can compared models ’s “real” model. Unsurprisingly, decision tree performs much better random model.
code: bespoke_spec <- bespoke(fn = random_baseline) %>%    parsnip::set_engine("bespoke", n_classes = 7)  bespoke_fit <- bespoke_spec %>%    parsnip::fit(class ~ ., oils)  predict(bespoke_fit, new_data = head(oils_no_classes), type = "class") #> # A tibble: 6 × 1 #>   .pred_class #>   <fct>       #> 1 rapeseed    #> 2 corn        #> 3 sunflower   #> 4 sunflower   #> 5 sunflower   #> 6 rapeseed predict(bespoke_fit, new_data = head(oils_no_classes), type = "prob") #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   .pred_corn .pred_olive .pred_peanut .pred_pumpkin .pred_rapeseed .pred_soybean #>        <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl>         <dbl> #> 1          1           0            0             0              0             0 #> 2          0           0            0             1              0             0 #> 3          0           0            0             0              0             0 #> 4          0           0            1             0              0             0 #> 5          0           0            1             0              0             0 #> 6          0           0            0             0              0             0 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: .pred_sunflower <dbl> tree_spec <- parsnip::decision_tree(mode = "classification") %>%    parsnip::set_engine(     engine = "rpart"   )  oil_set <- workflowsets::workflow_set(   preproc = list(class ~ .),   models = list(bespoke_spec, tree_spec) )  bs_oil <- rsample::bootstraps(oils)  oil_res <- oil_set %>%   workflowsets::workflow_map(     "fit_resamples",     resamples = bs_oil   ) #> → A | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for level: peanut. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1 #> → B | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for levels: corn and olive. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1→ C | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for levels: corn and peanut. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1→ D | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for level: corn. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1→ E | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for level: olive. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1There were issues with some computations   A: x2   B: x1   C: x4   D: x5   E: x1 #>  #> → A | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for level: peanut. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> → B | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for levels: corn and olive. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> → C | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for levels: corn and peanut. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1   B: x1   C: x2 #> → D | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for level: corn. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1   B: x1   C: x2→ E | warning: ✖ No observations were detected in `truth` for level: olive. #>                ℹ Computation will proceed by ignoring those levels. #> There were issues with some computations   A: x1   B: x1   C: x2There were issues with some computations   A: x2   B: x1   C: x4   D: x5   E: x1  workflowsets::rank_results(oil_res) #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   wflow_id          .config .metric  mean std_err     n preprocessor model  rank #>   <chr>             <chr>   <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl> <int> <chr>        <chr> <int> #> 1 formula_decision… Prepro… accura… 0.836  0.0215    25 formula      deci…     1 #> 2 formula_decision… Prepro… brier_… 0.119  0.0133    25 formula      deci…     1 #> 3 formula_decision… Prepro… roc_auc 0.890  0.0127    25 formula      deci…     1 #> 4 formula_bespoke   Prepro… accura… 0.122  0.0109    25 formula      besp…     2 #> 5 formula_bespoke   Prepro… brier_… 0.847  0.0128    25 formula      besp…     2 #> 6 formula_bespoke   Prepro… roc_auc 0.508  0.0116    25 formula      besp…     2

title: Manual Baseline Models
text: Sometimes makes sense define simple baseline model programmatically, using simple rules defined subject matter experts. However, can difficult compare models “real” models developed {tidymodels} framework. {bespoke} allows wrap hand-crafted “model” format fits within {tidymodels} framework.

title: Manual Baseline Models
text: Install development version bespoke GitHub:
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("macmillancontentscience/bespoke")

title: Manual Baseline Models
text: Please note bespoke project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: bespoke: Manual Baseline Models — bespoke-package
text: Create hand-crafted baseline models use tidymodels framework. "models"" use user-supplied functions make predictions, can used (example) tidymodels stack.

title: bespoke: Manual Baseline Models — bespoke-package
text: Maintainer: Jon Harmon jonthegeek@gmail.com (ORCID) Authors: Jonathan Bratt jonathan.bratt@macmillan.com (ORCID) contributors: Bedford Freeman & Worth Pub Grp LLC DBA Macmillan Learning [copyright holder]

title: Bespoke Models — bespoke
text: bespoke() defines model makes predictions using set function. "Training" model consists verifying output consistent types outputs seen training data; function tailored better predict training data. models can useful establishing baseline true models outperform.

title: Bespoke Models — bespoke
code: bespoke(mode = "classification", engine = "bespoke", fn = NULL)

title: Bespoke Models — bespoke
text: mode single character string prediction outcome mode. "classification" valid. engine single character string specifying computational engine use "fitting." "bespoke" valid. fn function takes data.frame input returns vector (integer, character, factor) indicating outcomes output (one value per input row). may someday extend probabilities.

title: Bespoke Models — bespoke
text: specification model.

title: Fit a bespoke_classification — bespoke_classification
text: bespoke_classification() produces fitted "model," model simply user-supplied function. Note , despite appearances, "model" actually trained fit data; put context "fitted" model order play nice tidymodels functions. , however, return member training outcomes input prediction.

title: Fit a bespoke_classification — bespoke_classification
code: bespoke_classification(x, ...)  # Default S3 method bespoke_classification(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' bespoke_classification(x, y, fn, ...)  # S3 method for class 'matrix' bespoke_classification(x, y, fn, ...)  # S3 method for class 'formula' bespoke_classification(formula, data, fn, ...)  # S3 method for class 'recipe' bespoke_classification(x, data, fn, ...)

title: Fit a bespoke_classification — bespoke_classification
text: x Depending context: data frame predictors. matrix predictors. recipe specifying set preprocessing steps created recipes::recipe(). ... Additional parameters passed model "function." y x data frame matrix, y outcome specified : data frame 1 numeric column. matrix 1 numeric column. numeric vector. fn function takes data.frame input returns vector (integer, character, factor) indicating outcomes output (one value per input row). may someday extend probabilities. formula formula specifying outcome terms left-hand side, predictor terms right-hand side. data recipe formula used, data specified : data frame containing predictors outcome.

title: Fit a bespoke_classification — bespoke_classification
text: bespoke_classification model object.
